title: 105_hr1362
content: The Act titled "Veterans Medicare Reimbursement Demonstration Act of 1997" establishes a demonstration project. The Act establishes a demonstration project where the Secretary of Health and Human Services provides reimbursement to the Department of Veterans Affairs for healthcare services to targeted Medicare-eligible veterans. The project will run for three years starting on January 1, 1998, with waivers for certain Medicare requirements if needed. The Secretaries will conduct a three-year demonstration project starting on January 1, 1998. The Secretary of Health and Human Services may waive Medicare requirements as needed. The Secretary of Veterans Affairs will select up to three geographic service areas for participating facilities. Veterans Affairs will designate up to three geographic service areas for facilities to participate in a demonstration project. The Secretary, in consultation with the Secretary of Health and Human Services, will establish a selection plan for facilities within the designated service areas to cater to targeted medicare-eligible veterans. The selection criteria will prioritize facilities with high potential demand from targeted medicare-eligible individuals. The selection plan for facilities in designated service areas will prioritize those suited to serve targeted medicare-eligible veterans based on demand, billing capability, quality indicators, and other relevant factors. At least one facility near a closed base will be selected. The selection plan for facilities in designated service areas will prioritize those suited to serve targeted medicare-eligible veterans based on demand, billing capability, quality indicators, and other relevant factors. At least one facility near a closed military base will be selected. The demonstration project for targeted medicare-eligible veterans is voluntary, with cost-sharing requirements similar to nongovernmental facilities. Payments received will be credited to the Department of Veterans Affairs medical appropriation. SEC. 3. DETERMINATION OF REIMBURSEMENT AMOUNTS. The Secretary of Health and Human Services will reimburse the Secretary of Veterans Affairs for services provided under a demonstration project at a rate equal to 95 percent of Medicare payment rates. Payments will be made periodically from Medicare trust funds. The Secretaries will establish rules for computing payment amounts for services provided under the demonstration project. Payments will be made periodically from Medicare trust funds, with an annual limit of $50,000,000. The demonstration project involves the Federal Hospital Insurance Trust Fund and the Federal Supplementary Medical Insurance Trust Fund. The annual limit on Medicare payments for the project is $50,000,000. Payment amounts may be reduced if the Department of Veterans Affairs fails to maintain efforts to cover costs for targeted Medicare-eligible veterans. For medicare-eligible veterans, payment amounts for the project may be reduced if actual VA medical expenditures for targeted veterans are less than the maintenance of effort level for the fiscal year. Maintenance of effort levels are determined based on previous fiscal year expenditures or fiscal year 1997 expenditures for targeted veterans. The maintenance of effort level for VA medical expenditures is determined based on the previous fiscal year or fiscal year 1997 expenditures for targeted veterans. It may be adjusted based on the percentage increase or decrease in the medical care appropriation for the Department of Veterans Affairs. The maintenance of effort level for VA medical expenditures is determined based on the previous fiscal year or fiscal year 1997 expenditures for targeted veterans. It may be adjusted based on the percentage increase or decrease in the medical care appropriation for the Department of Veterans Affairs. The VA medical expenditures are adjusted based on changes in appropriations and health care costs. The subsection discusses the impact of reduced medical care appropriations for the Department of Veterans Affairs on the delivery of services to targeted medicare-eligible veterans. It also defines VA medical expenditures for targeted veterans. The subsection addresses the impact of reduced medical care appropriations on VA medical expenditures for targeted medicare-eligible veterans, excluding certain expenditures. The subsection discusses the monitoring of expenditures under the medicare program for targeted medicare-eligible veterans to ensure no increase in costs, excluding specific expenditures. The Comptroller General audits expenditures made under the medicare program for targeted medicare-eligible veterans during a demonstration project to compare costs with and without the project. The report is submitted annually to Congress to assess any increase in costs for the Secretary of Health and Human Services. The Secretaries of Health and Human Services must report to Congress on any increase in costs under the medicare program due to a demonstration project. If costs have increased, steps must be taken to recoup the additional expenditures and prevent future increases. The Secretaries must take steps to recoup increased expenditures for the medicare program and prevent future increases. This includes payment from the Department of Veterans Affairs and suspending or terminating the project if necessary. The Secretary must recoup increased expenditures for the medicare program by using funds from the Department of Veterans Affairs and may suspend or terminate the project if needed. SEC. 4. EVALUATION AND REPORTS. The Secretaries will arrange for an independent entity to evaluate the health services demonstration project annually. The entity will submit reports to the Secretaries and Congress by March 1 each year, assessing the cost to the Department of Veterans Affairs and the quality of care provided by participating facilities. The evaluation of the health services demonstration project includes assessing the cost to the Department of Veterans Affairs, compliance of participating facilities with quality measures, comparison of costs and reimbursements, impact on Medicare programs, and changes in access to care for targeted veterans. The evaluation of the health services demonstration project includes assessing costs, compliance with quality measures, impact on Medicare programs, changes in access to care for targeted veterans, and recommendations for extension or expansion of the project. The Secretaries will submit a report to Congress within six months of the final report, recommending whether to extend or make permanent the demonstration project, expand it to cover more sites and increase reimbursement amounts, and continue or modify project terms. Additionally, by March 1, 1999, they will report on the feasibility of establishing a new demonstration project for payment to Managed Health-Care Plans. The Secretaries will submit a report to Congress by March 1, 1999, on the feasibility of a new demonstration project for payment to Managed Health-Care Plans for health care services for targeted medicare-eligible veterans. SEC. 5. DEFINITIONS. The terms "demonstration project" and "project" refer to the project under section 2(a). The term "geographic service area" pertains to a field component of the Veterans Health Administration based on natural patient referral patterns. The "medicare program" denotes health benefits under title XVIII of the Social Security Act. The term "medicare program" refers to health benefits provided under title XVIII of the Social Security Act. The term "Secretary" refers to the Secretary of Veterans Affairs and the Secretary of Health and Human Services acting jointly. A "targeted medicare-eligible veteran" is an individual who is a veteran described in section 101(2) of title 38, United States Code. A "targeted medicare-eligible veteran" is a veteran entitled to specific Medicare benefits with income falling within a defined range.
